Worst Case Scenarios

Offsite consequence analyses for the worst-case scenarios (WCS) were conducted using the Environmental Protection Agency's (EPA) RMP Offsite Consequence Analysis Guidelines. The RMP sets forth specific criteria that must be incorporated in modeling the worst-case scenarios. The EPA defines a WCS as one that results in the greatest distance from the point of release to a specified endpoint. As defined by the rule, the endpoint for a toxic substance is a specified concentration while for flammables it is a specified overpressure from a vapor cloud explosion (VCE).

The scenarios for the Oiltanking Texas City Marine Terminal were calculated using the EPA RMP*Comp Modeling Program which was downloaded from the EPA. Although numerous controls are in place to prevent chemical releases and manage such consequences should an incident occur, no credit for active mitigation measures was taken into account in evaluating these scenarios.

Alternative Release Scenarios

Alternative Release Scenarios (ARS) assess the potential hazards that are more realistic than worst-case scenarios and are designed to assist in the development of emergency response plans. EPA's RMP Offsite Consequence Analysis Guidelines were used in modeling the alternative release scenarios. Five- Year Accident History

The Oiltanking Marine Terminal, in the past five (5) years, has not incurred any chemical releases that resulted in any known onsite or offsite deaths, injuries, significant damage, evacuations or sheltering in place, property damage or environmental damage.   


Accidental Release Prevention Policies

The plans for evacuation and accounting for personnel after an evacuation at Oiltanking Marine Terminal, are located onsite for all personnel to review.

Description of the Facility and Purpose of Submittal

The Oiltanking Texas City Operations is a marine terminal loading/unloading and storage facility that annually stores more than five (5) billion pounds of chemicals including hydrocarbons, specialty polymers, solvents, intermediates, monomers and industrial products. The Oiltanking Marine Terminal is located approximately (5) miles south of Texas City and is involved in the transportation and distribution of chemicals and products. In accordance with U.S. EPA regulation 40 CFR 68, the U.S. EPA has identified quantities for 140 toxic or flammable substances that require a facility to comply with the Risk Management Program (RMP) rule when unit inventories exceed threshold quantities. The RMP rule requires a facility to report the unit inventory for each RMP substance that exceeds threshold quantities, along with an EPA approved chemical release prevention program. In addition, 40 CFR 68 requires all RMP covered facilities to update its Risk Management Plan (RMPlan) every five (5) years or six (6) months after an RMP reportable incident. This is the initial submittal of the RMPlan for the Oiltanking Marine Terminal. In compliance with 40 CFR 68, Oiltanking Marine Terminal is submitting the five (5) year plan as the initial RMPlan submittal.
